moves.2. g3: I was trying something new, so I decided to play g3 early.
moves.2... Nc6: He opens up his knight, protecting his pawn from any threats.
moves.3. Bg2: I get my bishop out of the way for castling.
moves.3... Nf6: He opens up his other knight - what I would usually do.
moves.4. Nf3: I decided to try to persuade him to take my pawn then threaten his knight repeatedly, but…
moves.4... a5: …He doesn't take my pawn, but instead pushes up his pawn on the wing up two squares, something that I think is pointless.
moves.5. d4: I threaten his pawn on e5 while being protected by my knight on f3 and my queen.
moves.5... d6: He protects his pawn using another one of his pawns.
moves.6... g6: He pushes up his pawn, same as I did on my second move.
moves.7. Re1: I protect my pawn with my rook.
moves.7... Be6: He opens up his bishop. I do this often.
moves.8. d5: I fork his knight and bishop with my pawn. :D
moves.8... Nd4: He threatens my knight, but it's easier for me to take his bishop with my pawn rather then taking the knight.
moves.9... Nxf3+: He takes my knight with his own, and I am now in check.
moves.10... fxe6: And he takes my free pawn. But notice that the other pawn is right in front of him. Now both of his e can't move anywhere.
moves.11... b6: He pushes up his pawn one square.
moves.12. Be3: I open up my other bishop. Now both my bishops and my knight are mobile and have a fair amount of space to move around in.
moves.12... Rg8: Not a great move. It isn't doing anything except preventing him from castling, unless he wants to open up his rook.
moves.13. Bg5: I pin the knight with my bishop.
moves.13... h6: He threatens me with a pawn.
moves.15... O-O-O:
He castles, but now I see something else, a possibility…
16. Na7+ Kb8 17. Nc6+! Forking the knight and rook!
moves.17. Nc6+: I fork his king and rook!
moves.17... Kc8: He moves his king out of the way and I happily capture his rook.
moves.18... Qxd8: He takes my knight, but now I'm plus 4 up with two rooks!
moves.19... h5: And he pushes up his own.
moves.20. b4: I threaten his a-pawn while being protected by my c-pawn.
moves.20... Be7: He ignores the threat and prepares to open up his bishop.
moves.21. Qa4: Now I'm really threatening his pawn.
moves.24. Be2:
Now I'm planning:
25. axb6 cxb6 26. Qa8+ Kd7 27. Bb5+
moves.24... g4: He pushes up his pawn again and now my plan can work.
moves.28. Qa7+: I check him with my queen, ignoring the queen swap.
moves.29. Ba6#:
I checkmate him with my bishop, my queen blocking his escape routes. :)
Believe it or not, I didn't actually checkmate him here in the blitz game. I actually played: Bc4! :D But then I won his rook and he reigned. Apart from not checkmating him in the blitz game, that was a great game!
